subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Kanayama tsuba?

Hi Jim, on the website you write: ' These tsuba appear to have been
finished by slightly melting the surface after forging and shaping. This
brings out tekkotsu from the high carbon inclusions in the iron'
 
Was this done at any other schools or is this peculiar to Kanayama? 
 
Als if you had to translate 'tekkotsu' in English what would it be? I
know what it is (at least I think I do) but I can't for the life of me
think what you would call it in English. 
 
Matt

Van: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...] 
Verzonden: dinsdag 20 januari 2004 1:31
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Kanayama tsuba?


Matt,
I think that the metal and the tekkotsu are the first points for
Kanayama.  The distinctive motifs would place second (or is that third).
Not all Kanayama guards have wide seppa dai.  Earthlink has told me that
my site has already exceeded its bandwidth allotment (it's happening
earlier and earlier in the month), but it hasn't been shut down yet, so
quickly check:

http://home.earthlink.net/~jggilbert/kanayama.htm

Some of them have rather narrow seppa dai.

You're following the right process.  
Jim



  I think that they went out of fashion is indeed a much more plausible
  explanation....... however it is always fun to think about what might
  have been. Continuing the subject of Kanayama tsuba, would you say
that
  the 'quite large seppa dai in proportion to the rest of the guard'
  feature on this type of tsuba is a kantei point? For some reason they
  all seem to have a larger seppa dai in relation to the rest of the
  design than most other tsuba. 

  Other kantei points would be the type of steel, the color, the
tekkotsu,
  the designs used (often hard to figure out what they represent) etc. 

  Am I missing any here?

  I seem to be getting the knack of distinguishing what is what with all
  these different tsuba :- / but that is only because I have spent ages
  and ages looking at all kinds of stuff and remembering what such and
  such looked like an what school it was. Now I am trying to pinpoint
  specific features to help attribute guards more correctly and date
them.
  Much like you would do with porcleain with decorative motives and the
  paste of the porcelain. 

  Matt.

  Van: Jim Gilbert [mailto:jggilbert@...] 
  Verzonden: maandag 19 januari 2004 21:37
  Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
  Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Kanayama tsuba?


  Matt,
  The short answer is that I don't know.  

  But, I tend to doubt it.  The Norisuke working in the 19th C produced
  tekkotsu at will and in their copies sometimes exaggerated them beyond
  what was in the originals.  Good Kanayama work is still more
attractive,
  but how much of that is because of raw material vs. technique vs.
  intent?

  It's quite possible that Kanayama guards simply went out of style.
The
  aesthetic trend in the Edo period moved away from the tastes of the
  Muromachi and Momoyama in paintings, ceramics, etc., as well as sword
  fittings. 
  Jim



    Gang, how much truth is there to the theory that the Kanayama tsuba
    makers used a 'special secret iron ore known only the them and
  probably
    close to where they worked' that produced the wonderful tekkotsu
  effects
    in their tsuba? And that when the when they ran out of this
particular
    iron ore the school ceased to exist?

    Matt
